doc.field: Close up of the Angel from above. I'm pleased with the overall shape. Model I built for Lego's "My Way" project with schools in the UK. The real statue is 30m tall and located near Newcastle. It will be sent to a school near there for the children to dismantle and make something of their own. I will hopefuilly be going along with it to advise.

As part of the Lego "My Way" project, I built a Lego model of Antony Gormley's Angel of the North. This was taken to Hotspur School in Newcastle where the children demolished the model (in about 5 minutes) and we designed and built a new model out of the pieces. We chose to build the "Monster on the Mound", a brown and green monster with one eye, a big beard and hat and three giant feet. On the way to the school, we passed the real Angel of the North. It was a beautiful morning, so it would have been a crime not to stop for a photo opportunity.
england monster newcastle lego angelofthenorth antonygormley monsteronthemound

Lego "My Way" Project: Angel of the North

Close up of the body. It's rather fragile around the ankles, but remained upright and even survived a light breeze. Model I built for Lego's "My Way" project with schools in the UK. The real statue is 30m tall and located near Newcastle. It will be sent to a school near there for the children to dismantle and make something of their own. I will hopefuilly be going along with it to advise.

Me and my model. I should have taken one lying down as the wings stretch out longer than I do! The wingspan is over 2 metres. It's supported by a long supporting arm made from technic bricks that runs through the shoulders. the wing membranes are made of plates and suspended from the arms, with a slot in the body that they slide into. Model I built for Lego's "My Way" project with schools in the UK. The real statue is 30m tall and located near Newcastle. It will be sent to a school near there for the children to dismantle and make something of their own. I will hopefuilly be going along with it to advise.

View from the wingtip. The top beam is made up of technic beams and 1x4 bricks with studs on the sides (launderettes) to grip onto the plate built wing. I suspect it's getting close to the limit of what's possible to support without glue or a metal frame. Model I built for Lego's "My Way" project with schools in the UK. The real statue is 30m tall and located near Newcastle. It will be sent to a school near there for the children to dismantle and make something of their own. I will hopefuilly be going along with it to advise.

Work in progress on the torso. The first photo I took after I retrieved my camera and the bag I'd left on a train. Model I built for Lego's "My Way" project with schools in the UK. The real statue is 30m tall and located near Newcastle. It will be sent to a school near there for the children to dismantle and make something of their own. I will hopefully be going along with it to advise.
Angel of the North - work in progress 1

My first attempt at attaching a wing - it had to be supported to stay in place without the other wing to counterbalance. Shortly after this, I fumbled the dismount and disaster struck. Fortunately it only broke into a few pieces and went back together fairly quickly. Model I built for Lego's "My Way" project with schools in the UK. The real statue is 30m tall and located near Newcastle. It will be sent to a school near there for the children to dismantle and make something of their own. I will hopefuilly be going along with it to advise.

Angel of the North - work in progress

The body and a partially completed wing. I actually built the wing first because I wanted to test that my idea was plausable - I didn't have enough plate in my own collection to test such a large area. Model I built for Lego's "My Way" project with schools in the UK. The real statue is 30m tall and located near Newcastle. It will be sent to a school near there for the children to dismantle and make something of their own. I will hopefuilly be going along with it to advise.

Angel of the North - work in progress

The tirst time we tried putting both wings on. To our amazement it stayed upright, though Duncan stayed close in case it looked like it was about to come crashing down. Note Duncan's work-in-progress on Blackpool Tower in the background. Model I built for Lego's "My Way" project with schools in the UK. The real statue is 30m tall and located near Newcastle. It will be sent to a school near there for the children to dismantle and make something of their own. I will hopefuilly be going along with it to advise.
